Authors: Japutra A., Utami A.F., Molinillo S., Ekaputra I.A.
Title: Influence of customer application experience and value in use on loyalty toward retailers
Source title: Journal of Retailing and Consumer Services
Affiliations: Business School, University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia; Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, Indonesia; Management Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Malaga, Malaga, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Japutra, A., Business School, University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia; Utami, A.F., Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, Indonesia, Management Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Molinillo, S., Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Malaga, Malaga, Spain; Ekaputra, I.A., Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, Indonesia
Abstract: This study aims to explain the mechanism by which user experience with retailer applications could lead to loyalty toward retailers. The data were collected through a survey in Indonesia (n = 717). The results support the positive impact of customer experience (i.e., sensorial experiential state, affective experiential state, interactivity, and relative advantage) on value in use. Value in use mediates the effects of customer experience on satisfaction and loyalty toward retailer application. In turn, these two constructs increase loyalty toward the retailer. These findings contribute to the theoretical and practical understanding of the impact of retailer applications on the customer-retailer relationship. © 2020 Elsevier Ltd
Author Keywords: Customer experience; Customer loyalty; Customer satisfaction; Retailer application; Value in use
Index Keywords: consumption behavior; market conditions; retailing; Indonesia
Funding Details:
Universitas Indonesia, UI: NKB-0813/UN2.R3.1/HKP.05.00/2019

Authors: Ande D.F., Utami A.F., Soetjipto B.W.
Title: Politics, fairness, trust and intention to leave in family business
Source title: International Journal of Learning and Change
Affiliations: Faculty Economics and Business, University of Indonesia, Kota Depok, Jawa Barat, 16424, Indonesia; School of Management and Leadership, Tanri Abeng University, Ulujami, Jak-Sel, 12250, Indonesia; School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Universitas Pertamina, Kebayoran Lama, Jakarta, 12220, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ande, D.F., Faculty Economics and Business, University of Indonesia, Kota Depok, Jawa Barat, 16424, Indonesia, School of Management and Leadership, Tanri Abeng University, Ulujami, Jak-Sel, 12250, Indonesia; Utami, A.F., Faculty Economics and Business, University of Indonesia, Kota Depok, Jawa Barat, 16424, Indonesia, School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Soetjipto, B.W., Faculty Economics and Business, University of Indonesia, Kota Depok, Jawa Barat, 16424, Indonesia, Universitas Pertamina, Kebayoran Lama, Jakarta, 12220, Indonesia
Abstract: This study is aimed to examine the influence of office politics, fairness, and trust in leader on employee intention to leave in the higher education family-owned company in Indonesia. This study utilised quantitative method with 116 sample sizes. Previous study shows that the most prominent challenge for the family business is to maintain the fairness within the company. In this matter, there are possibilities that the tense organisation politics might be higher than other organisations. Moreover, trust in leader is also imperative, since family-owned business is highly symbolised by the family member as the leaders. Unfortunately, while these factors appeared to be pivotal, it can influence the turnover intention of the employee. This might be imperative due to its detrimental effect on the successor availability. The study found that the higher the employee perceived the political action in the company, the higher the employee’s intention to leave. Copyright © 2020 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: Fairness; Family business; Intention to leave; Organisational politics; Trust

Authors: Utami A.F., Triady M.S., Nur Suci R.P.
Title: Working values preferences among Gen-X, Y and baby boomers in Indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Jalur Sutera Barat Kav.21 Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Utami, A.F., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Jalur Sutera Barat Kav.21 Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia; Triady, M.S., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Jalur Sutera Barat Kav.21 Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia; Nur Suci, R.P., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Jalur Sutera Barat Kav.21 Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia
Abstract: This study analyses work value preferences across generational workforce of employees in Indonesia using quantitative approach based on Twenge Campbell, Hoffman and Lance (2010). The dimensions of work values include extrinsic values, intrinsic values, leisure, altruistic and social rewards. A total of 429 people were recruited for this study via an online survey. Statistical approaches, namely Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and Tukey’s Honestly Significant Difference (HSD), were used to analyse data obtained from the questionnaire. The ANOVA result indicated differences between the three generational cohorts in five work-values. The result showed that Generation Y valued leisure rewards higher than Gen-X and Baby Boomers while the latter placed higher value on social rewards than Gen-X and Gen-Y. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Baby Boomers; Dimensions of work values; Generation X; Generation Y; Work-value

Authors: Hamali S., Suci R.P.N., Utami A.F., Hanisman, Arga F.
Title: Using analytic hierarchy process and Decision Tree for a production decision making
Source title: Proceedings of 2016 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2016
Affiliations: School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; PhD Candidate in Economics, University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, Illinois, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hamali, S., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Suci, R.P.N., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Utami, A.F., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Hanisman, School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Arga, F., PhD Candidate in Economics, University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, Illinois, United States
Abstract: Today, the light weight bricks are on high demand in the market, where 'X' is considering to expand its' business to produce this product. However, expanding business to a new business lines requires a comprehensive considerations. Complexity of decision-making not only lies in the uncertainty or the imperfections of information, but involves many criteria and sub-criteria used to rank the alternatives of a decision. The purpose of this study is to understand the best solution on whether or not the light weight bricks being produced by 'X'. Hence, this study applied the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) and Decision Tree Analysis (DTA) as the rational decision making tools may help 'X' to decide whether or not to invest in the new business line. The results based on data processing AHP of directors and general managers indicate that the 'X' has a tendency to decide to make the light weight bricks. While based on the DTA shows that the 'X' will benefit if it decides to make the light weight bricks. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Analytic Hierarchy Process; Decision Tree Analysis; Expected Monetary Value; Light weight bricks; Multi-criteria
Index Keywords: Analytic hierarchy process; Brick; Data handling; Decision trees; Hierarchical systems; Information management; Analytic hierarchy process (ahp); Decision tree analysis; Expanding business; Expected monetary values; Light weight; Multi-criteria; Production decisions; Rational decision making; Decision making
References: Saaty, T.L., Vargas, L.G., Models, methods, concepts & applications of the analytic hierarchy process (2012) International Series in Operations Research & Management Science, 175. , Springer Science+Business Media New York; Heizer, J., Render, B., (2011) Operation Management, , 10th ed., New Jersey; Vidal, L.-A., Marle, F., Bocquet, J.-C., Using a delphi process and the analytic hierarchy process (ahp) to evaluate the complexity of projects (2011) Expert Systems with Applications, 38 (5), pp. 5388-5405; Dey, P.K., Project risk management: A combined analytic hierarchy process and decision tree approach (2002) Cost Engineering, 44 (3), pp. 13-27; Battistoni, E., Colladon, A.F., Scarabotti, L., Schiraldi, M.M., Analytic hierarchy process for new product development (2013) International Journal of Engineering Business Management, 5; Liao, W.-H., Qiu, W., Applying analytic hierarchy process to assess healthcare-oriented cloud computing service systems (2016) SpringerPlus, 5 (1), p. 1030; Harjanto, E., Manajemen Operasi (2008) Cetakan Ketujuh, Jakarta

Authors: Triady M.S., Kurniasari R., Utami A.F., Sofyan M.I.
Title: Investigation of leverage effect in Indonesian stock market
Source title: International Journal of Economics and Management
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 15325, Indonesia; Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, 40132, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Triady, M.S., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 15325, Indonesia; Kurniasari, R., Institut Teknologi Bandung, Bandung, 40132, Indonesia; Utami, A.F., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 15325, Indonesia; Sofyan, M.I., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 15325, Indonesia
Abstract: Financial market is a very dynamic market, and then it will be an advantage for the industry to know the market behavior as an advisement for making decision. This study aims to find the behavior of Indonesian Stock Market by empirically investigating its volatility pattern using daily return series. In order to find more evidences, this study examines the stock market in certain condition that gave big shocks to the market by examining the condition during the global financial crisis of 2008/2009. We use both symmetric and asymmetric Generalized Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedasticity (GARCH) to model the conditional mean and the conditional variance in order to examine asymmetric and leverage effect in Indonesian Stock Market. Using Jakarta Composite Index (JCI) divided into two periods, the first period is from 2001 to 2007, before global financial crisis happened, and the second one includes the financial crisis, from 2001 to 2012. EGARCH (1,1) is found as the best fitting and also the best forecasting performance model in modeling volatility of returns. The market also shows the existence of leverage effect in both periods and this leverage effect increases in period with crisis.
Author Keywords: GARCH; Indonesian stock market; Leverage effect; Volatility
References: Albaity, M., Ahmad, R., Return performance, leverage effect, and volatility spillover in Islamic stock indices evidence from DJIMI, FTSEGII, and KLSI (2011) Investment Management and Financial Innovations, 8 (3);
